<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Subordinated
 guaranties provided to some Alcatel-Lucent and Alcatel-Lucent USA Inc. (ex.Lucent Technologies Inc. (&#147;Lucent&#148;)) public bonds </FONT></I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"><U>Alcatel-Lucent
 guaranty of Lucent Technologies Inc. 2.875&nbsp;% Series A &amp; B Convertibles</U> </FONT></I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On December&nbsp;29,
2006, Alcatel-Lucent provided its full and unconditional guaranty to Lucent&#146;s 2.875&nbsp;% Series A Convertible Senior Debentures due 2023 and to Lucent&#146;s 2.875&nbsp;% Series B Convertible Senior Debentures due 2025. These guarantees were
delivered as part of a joint solicitation of consent from the holders of such debentures and are unsecured and subordinated to Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s senior debt. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"><U>Lucent
guaranty of Alcatel-Lucent public bonds</U> </FONT></I></FONT></P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On March&nbsp;27, 2007, Lucent provided its full and
unconditional guaranty to the following Alcatel-Lucent public bonds: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="19"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="18" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#7f6bba">&#149;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Oceane 4.75&nbsp;% due January&nbsp;2011; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="19"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="18" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#7f6bba">&#149;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">6.375&nbsp;% EUR due April&nbsp;2014 </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">These guarantees are unsecured and subordinated to Lucent&#146;s senior debt.
</FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5"><B><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#333333">N<SMALL>OTE
</SMALL> 23. C<SMALL>ONTINGENCIES</SMALL> </FONT></I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In addition to legal proceedings incidental to the conduct of its business
(including employment-related collective actions in France and the United States) which management believes are adequately reserved against in the financial statements or will not result in any significant costs to the Group, Alcatel-Lucent is
involved in the following legal proceedings. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">a/ Costa
Rica </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Beginning in early October 2004, Alcatel-Lucent learned that investigations had been launched in
Costa Rica by the Costa Rican prosecutors and the National Congress, regarding payments alleged to have been made by consultants on behalf of Alcatel CIT, a French subsidiary now called Alcatel-Lucent France (&#147;CIT&#148;), or other
Alcatel-Lucent subsidiaries to various public officials in Costa Rica, two political parties in Costa Rica and representatives of Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad (ICE), the state-owned telephone company, in connection with the procurement by
CIT of several contracts for network equipment and services from ICE. Upon learning of these allegations, Alcatel commenced an investigation into this matter. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent terminated the employment of the then-president of Alcatel de Costa Rica in October 2004 and of a vice president
Latin America of CIT. CIT is also pursuing criminal actions in France against the latter and in Costa Rica against these two former employees and certain local
</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
consultants, based on their complicity in a bribery scheme and misappropriation of funds. The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) and the United States Department
of Justice (&#147;DOJ&#148;) are aware of the allegations and Alcatel-Lucent stated it would cooperate fully in any inquiry or investigation into these matters. The SEC and the DOJ are conducting an investigation into possible violations of the
Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (&#147;FCPA&#148;) and the federal securities laws. In connection with that investigation, the DOJ and the SEC also requested information regarding Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s operations in other countries. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In connection with these allegations, on December&nbsp;19, 2006, the DOJ indicted one of the two former employees on charges of
violations of the FCPA, money laundering, and conspiracy. On March&nbsp;20, 2007, a grand jury returned a superseding indictment against the same former employee and the former president of Alcatel de Costa Rica, based on the same allegations
contained in the previous indictment. On June&nbsp;11, 2007, the former CIT employee entered into a plea agreement in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida and pleaded guilty to violations of the FCPA. On September&nbsp;23,
2008, the former CIT employee was sentenced to 30 months&#146; imprisonment, three years&#146; supervised release, the forfeiture of US$&nbsp;261,500, and a US$&nbsp;200 special assessment. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">French authorities are also conducting an investigation of CIT&#146;s payments to consultants in the Costa Rica matter.
</FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>82</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report 2010 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent is cooperating with the U.S., French and Costa Rican authorities in
the respective investigations described above. Alcatel-Lucent reiterates that its policy is to conduct its business with transparency, and in compliance with all laws and regulations, both locally and internationally. Alcatel-Lucent will cooperate
with all governmental authorities in connection with the investigation of any violation of those laws and regulations. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In connection with the Costa Rica allegations, on July&nbsp;27, 2007, the Costa Rican Prosecutor&#146;s Office indicted eleven
individuals, including the former president of Alcatel de Costa Rica, on charges of aggravated corruption, unlawful enrichment, simulation, fraud and others. Three of those individuals have since pled guilty. Shortly thereafter, the Costa Rican
Attorney General&#146;s Office and ICE, acting as victims of this criminal case, each filed amended civil claims against the eleven criminal defendants, as well as five additional civil defendants (one individual and four corporations, including
CIT) seeking compensation for damages in the amounts of US$&nbsp;52&nbsp;million (in the case of the Attorney General&#146;s Office) and U.S. $&nbsp;20&nbsp;million (in the case of ICE). The Attorney General&#146;s claim supersedes two prior claims,
of November&nbsp;25, 2004 and August&nbsp;31, 2006. On November&nbsp;25, 2004, the Costa Rican Attorney General&#146;s Office commenced a civil lawsuit against CIT to seek pecuniary compensation for the damage caused by the alleged payments
described above to the people and the Treasury of Costa Rica, and for the loss of prestige suffered by the Nation of Costa Rica (social damages). The ICE claim, which supersedes its prior claim of February&nbsp;1, 2005, seeks pecuniary compensation
for the damage caused by the alleged payments described above to ICE and its customers, for the harm to the reputation of ICE resulting from these events (moral damages), and for damages resulting from an alleged overpricing it was forced to pay
under its contract with CIT. During preliminary court hearings held in San Jos&eacute; during September&nbsp;2008, ICE filed a report in which the damages allegedly caused by CIT are valued at US$&nbsp;71.6&nbsp;million. No formal notice of a
revised civil claim has so far been received by CIT. The trial of the criminal case started on April&nbsp;14, 2010 and is ongoing. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent entered into discussions with the Attorney General&#146;s Office directed to a negotiated resolution of the
Attorney General&#146;s social damages claims and the moral damages claims of ICE. Those discussions resulted in a signed agreement entered into on January&nbsp;20, 2010 under
</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
which the Attorney General&#146;s social damages claims were dismissed in return for a payment by CIT of approximately US$&nbsp;10&nbsp;million. That agreement was approved by the Court having
jurisdiction over the Attorney General&#146;s claims on February&nbsp;24, 2010 and payment was made shortly thereafter. ICE&#146;s claims are not included in the agreement with the Attorney General. To the extent that any of these claims are not
resolved by agreement, Alcatel-Lucent intends to defend against them vigorously and to deny any liability or wrongdoing with respect to such claims. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Additionally, in August&nbsp;2007, ICE notified CIT of the commencement of an administrative proceeding to terminate the 2001
contract for CIT to install 400,000 GSM cellular telephone lines (the &#147;400KL GSM Contract&#148;), in connection with which ICE is claiming compensation of US$&nbsp;59.8&nbsp;million for damages and loss of income. By March&nbsp;2008, CIT and
ICE concluded negotiations of a draft settlement agreement for the implementation of a &#147;Get Well Plan,&#148; in full and final settlement of the above-mentioned claim. This settlement agreement was not approved by ICE&#146;s Board of Directors
that resolved, instead, to resume the aforementioned administrative proceedings to terminate the operations and maintenance portion of the 400KL GSM Contract, claim penalties and damages in the amount of US$&nbsp;59.8&nbsp;million and call the
performance bond. CIT was notified of the termination by ICE of this portion of the 400 KL GSM Contract on June&nbsp;23, 2008. ICE has made additional damages claims and penalty assessments related to the 400KL GSM Contract that bring the overall
exposure under the contract to US$&nbsp;78.1&nbsp;million in the aggregate, of which ICE has collected US$&nbsp;5.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In June&nbsp;2008, CIT filed an administrative appeal against the termination mentioned above. ICE called the performance bond in
August&nbsp;2008, and on September&nbsp;16, 2008 CIT was served notice of ICE&#146;s request for payment of the remainder amount of damages claimed, US$&nbsp;44.7&nbsp;million. On September&nbsp;17, 2008, the Costa Rican Supreme Court ruled on the
appeal filed by CIT stating that: (i)&nbsp;the US$&nbsp;15.1&nbsp;million performance bond amount is to be reimbursed to CIT and (ii)&nbsp;the US$&nbsp;44.7&nbsp;million claim is to remain suspended until final resolution by the competent court of
the case. Following a clarification request filed by ICE, the Court finally decided that the US$&nbsp;15.1&nbsp;million performance bond amount is to remain deposited in an escrow account held by the Court, until final resolution of the case. On
October&nbsp;8, 2008, CIT filed a claim against ICE requesting the court to overrule ICE&#146;s partial termination regarding the
</FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report
2010&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>83</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
400KL GSM Contract and claiming compensation for the damages caused to CIT. In January&nbsp;2009, ICE filed its response to CIT&#146;s claim. At a court hearing on March&nbsp;25, 2009, ICE ruled
out entering into settlement discussions with CIT. On April&nbsp;20, 2009, CIT filed a petition to the Court to recover the US$&nbsp;15.1&nbsp;million performance bond amount and offered the replacement of such bond with a new bond that will
guarantee the results of the final decision of the Court. CIT appealed the Court&#146;s rejection of such petition and the appeal was resolved on March&nbsp;18, 2010 in favor of CIT. As a consequence of this resolution, CIT will collect the
aforementioned US$&nbsp;15.1&nbsp;million amount upon submission to the Court of a bank guarantee for an equivalent amount. A hearing originally scheduled for June&nbsp;1, 2009 was suspended due to ICE&#146;s decision not to present to the Court the
complete administrative file wherein ICE decided the partial termination of the 400KL GSM Contract. The preliminary court hearing, which commenced on October&nbsp;6, 2009, recently concluded and the case will proximately be set for trial.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On October&nbsp;14, 2008, the Costa Rican authorities notified CIT of the commencement of an administrative
proceeding to ban CIT from government procurement contracts in Costa Rica for up to 5 years. The administrative proceeding was suspended on December&nbsp;8, 2009 pending the resolution of the criminal case mentioned above. In March&nbsp;2010, CIT
was notified of a new administrative proceeding whereby ICE seeks to ban CIT from procurement contracts, as a consequence of alleged material breaches under the 400KL GSM Contract (in particular, in connection with failures related to road coverage
and quality levels). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">If the Costa Rican authorities conclude criminal violations have occurred, CIT may be banned
from participating in government procurement contracts within Costa Rica for a certain period. Alcatel-Lucent expects to generate approximately
<FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">&#128;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT>&nbsp;3&nbsp;million in revenue from Costa Rican contracts in 2010. Based on the amount of revenue
expected from these contracts, Alcatel-Lucent does not believe a loss of business in Costa Rica would have a material adverse effect on the Alcatel-Lucent group as a whole. However, these events may have a negative impact on the reputation of
Alcatel-Lucent in Latin America. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent has recognized a provision in connection with the various ongoing
proceedings in Costa Rica when reliable estimates of the probable future outflow were available. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
  <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On April 30, 2010 ICE filed a civil RICO claim in state court in Miami, Florida
(USA). ICE claims that several different Alcatel-Lucent entities, along with a former employee, were engaged in a worldwide scheme of bribery and corruption, during which it made payments to senior officials of the Costa Rican government and ICE.
ICE claims it was damaged from this conduct and seeks treble damages, disgorgement, and other damages and relief. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">As previously disclosed in its public filings, Alcatel-Lucent has engaged in settlement discussions with the DOJ and the SEC with
regard to the ongoing FCPA investigations. These discussions have resulted in December&nbsp;2009 in agreements in principle with the staffs of each of the agencies. There can be no assurances, however, that final agreements will be reached with the
agencies or accepted in court. If finalized, the agreements would relate to alleged violations of the FCPA involving several countries, including Costa Rica, Taiwan, and Kenya. Under the agreement in principle with the SEC, Alcatel-Lucent would
enter into a consent decree under which Alcatel-Lucent would neither admit nor deny violations of the antibribery, internal controls and books and records provisions of the FCPA and would be enjoined from future violations of U.S. securities laws,
pay US$&nbsp;45.4&nbsp;million in disgorgement of profits and prejudgment interest and agree to a three-year French anticorruption compliance monitor to evaluate in accordance with the provisions of the consent decree (unless any specific provision
therein is expressly determined by the French Ministry of Justice to violate French law) the effectiveness of Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s internal controls, record-keeping and financial reporting policies and procedures. Under the agreement in principle
with the DOJ, Alcatel-Lucent would enter into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement (DPA), charging Alcatel-Lucent with violations of the internal controls and books and records provisions of the FCPA, and Alcatel-Lucent would pay a total
criminal fine of US$&nbsp;92&nbsp;million - payable in four installments over the course of three years. In addition, three Alcatel-Lucent subsidiaries - Alcatel-Lucent France, Alcatel-Lucent Trade International AG and Alcatel Centroamerica - would
each plead guilty to violations of the FCPA&#146;s antibribery, books and records and internal accounting controls provisions. The agreement with the DOJ would also contain provisions relating to a three-year French anticorruption compliance
monitor. If Alcatel-Lucent fully complies with the terms of the DPA, the DOJ would dismiss the charges upon conclusion of the three-year term. </FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>84</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report 2010 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent has recognized a provision of
<FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">&#128;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT>&nbsp;110&nbsp;million as of June&nbsp;30, 2010 in connection with these FCPA investigations, which is
equivalent to the sum of US$&nbsp;45.4&nbsp;million as agreed upon in the agreement in principle with the SEC and US$&nbsp;92&nbsp;million as agreed upon in the agreement in principle with the DOJ, discounted back to net present value and converted
into Euros. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">b/ Taiwan
</FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Certain employees of Taisel, a Taiwanese affiliate of Alcatel-Lucent, and Siemens&#146;s Taiwanese
distributor, along with a few suppliers and a legislative aide, have been the subject of an investigation by the Taipei Investigator&#146;s Office of the Ministry of Justice relating to an axle counter supply contract awarded to Taisel by Taiwan
Railways in 2003. It has been alleged that persons in Taisel, Alcatel-Lucent Deutschland AG (a German subsidiary of Alcatel-Lucent involved in the Taiwan Railway contract), Siemens Taiwan, and subcontractors hired by them were involved in a
bid-rigging and illicit payment arrangement for the Taiwan Railways contract. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Upon learning of these allegations,
Alcatel-Lucent commenced an investigation into this matter. As a result of the investigation, Alcatel-Lucent terminated the former president of Taisel. A director of international sales and marketing development of the German subsidiary resigned
during the investigation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On February&nbsp;21, 2005, Taisel, the former president of Taisel, and others were indicted
in Taiwan for violation of the Taiwanese Government Procurement Act. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On November&nbsp;15, 2005, the Taipei criminal
district court found Taisel not guilty of the alleged violation of the Government Procurement Act. The former President of Taisel was not judged because he was not present or represented at the proceedings. The court found two Taiwanese businessmen
involved in the matter guilty of violations of the Business Accounting Act. The not guilty verdict for Taisel was upheld by the Taiwan High Court and is now final. On December&nbsp;9, 2009, the Supreme Court denied the appeal filed by the Taiwan
Prosecutor Office against the High Court&#146;s ruling with respect to the individual defendants. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Other allegations
made in connection with this matter may still be under ongoing investigation by the Taiwanese authorities. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">c/ Kenya
and Nigeria </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">The SEC and the DOJ asked Alcatel-Lucent to look into payments made in 2000 by CIT to a
consultant arising out of a supply contract between CIT and a privately-owned company in Kenya. Alcatel-Lucent understands that the French authorities are also conducting an investigation to ascertain whether inappropriate payments were received by
foreign public officials in connection with such project. Alcatel-Lucent is cooperating with the U.S. and French authorities and has submitted to these authorities its findings regarding those payments. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Following information voluntarily disclosed by Alcatel-Lucent to the US and French authorities, the French authorities have
requested Alcatel-Lucent to produce further documents related to payments made by its subsidiaries to certain consultants in Nigeria. Alcatel-Lucent has responded to the request and is continuing to cooperate with the investigating authorities.
</FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">d/ French
Polynesia </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">The French authorities have initiated an investigation of the submarine cable subsidiary of
Alcatel-Lucent, Alcatel-Lucent Submarine Networks (&#147;ALSN&#148;), and certain former or current employees, relating to a project for a submarine cable between Tahiti and Hawaii awarded to ALSN in 2007 by the state-owned telecom agency of French
Polynesia (&#147;OPT&#148;). On September&nbsp;23, 2009, four of those employees were charged (&#147;mis en examen&#148;) with aiding and abetting favoritism in connection with the award by OPT of a public procurement project. On November&nbsp;23,
2009, ALSN was charged with benefitting from favoritism (&#147;recel de favoritisme&#148;) in connection with the same alleged favoritism. Alcatel-Lucent commenced, and is continuing, an investigation into this matter. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Alcatel-Lucent is unable to predict the outcome of this investigation and its effect on ALSN&#146;s business. If ALSN were
convicted of a criminal violation, the French courts could, among other things, fine ALSN and/or ban it from participating in French public procurement contracts for a certain period. ALSN expects to generate approximately
<FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">&#128;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT>&nbsp;18&nbsp;million of revenue from French public procurement contracts in 2010. Accordingly,
Alcatel-Lucent does not believe that a loss of business as a result of such a ban would have a material effect on the Alcatel-Lucent group as a whole. </FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report
2010&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>85</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">e/
Lucent&#146;s employment and benefits related cases </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In October 2005, a purported class action was filed by
Peter A. Raetsch, Geraldine Raetsch and Curtis Shiflett, on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey. The plaintiffs alleged that Lucent failed to maintain health care benefits
for retired management employees for each year from 2001 through 2006 as required by the Internal Revenue Code, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, and the Lucent pension and medical plans. Upon motion by Lucent, the court remanded the
claims to Lucent&#146;s claims review process. A Special Committee was appointed and reviewed the claims of the plaintiffs and Lucent filed a report with the Court on December&nbsp;28, 2006. The Special Committee denied the plaintiffs&#146; claims
and the case returned to the court, where limited discovery was completed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">By Opinion and Order, each dated
June&nbsp;11, 2008, the court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs&#146; motion for summary judgment (as to liability) and denied Lucent&#146;s cross-motion for summary judgment (also as to liability). Specifically, the court found that
Lucent had violated the Plan&#146;s maintenance of benefits requirement with respect to the 2003 plan year but that the record before the court contained insufficient facts from which to conclude whether those provisions were violated for years
prior to 2003. The court also &#147;tentatively&#148; ruled that defendants had not violated the Plan&#146;s maintenance of cost provisions for the years 2004 through 2006. The court ordered the parties to engage in further discovery proceedings.
Finally, the court denied, without prejudice, plaintiff&#146;s motion for class certification. On June&nbsp;26, 2008, Lucent requested the court to certify the case for appeal to the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in its discretion. This request was
denied. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">As a result of the court&#146;s findings for 2003, Lucent established a provision for U.S.
$&nbsp;27&nbsp;million during the second quarter of 2008. As a result of the ongoing discovery and analysis, this reserve was adjusted from time to time. On January&nbsp;21, 2010, the parties agreed to settle the lawsuit for the sum of
US$&nbsp;36&nbsp;million. The settlement is memorialized in a binding and executed Settlement Agreement. The settlement is subject to court approval, including approval of the settlement amount and the amount of class counsel&#146;s fees to be
deducted therefrom, approval of a plan of allocation of the net settlement
</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
proceeds to class members, and certification of a settlement class by the court. On June&nbsp;3, 2010, the court indicated its preliminary approval of the settlement and set September&nbsp;10,
2010 as the deadline for filing objections and September&nbsp;27, 2010 as the date for a final hearing. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Lucent
implemented various actions to address the rising costs of providing retiree health care benefits and the funding of Lucent pension plans. These actions led to the filing of cases against Lucent (now closed) and may lead to the filing of additional
cases. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In September&nbsp;2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) had filed a purported class action
lawsuit against Lucent, EEOC v. Lucent Technologies Inc., in the U.S. District Court in California, for gender discrimination with respect to the provision of service credit for purposes of a pension plan. In a case concerning a similar plan, the
U.S. Supreme Court decided in May&nbsp;2009 that such plan is not unlawful unless there is evidence of intentional discrimination. In </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">light of this judgment, the EEOC voluntarily dismissed this matter, and the dismissal was approved by the District Court on
July&nbsp;27, 2009. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">f/
Intellectual property cases </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Each of Alcatel-Lucent, Lucent and certain other entities of the Group is a
defendant in various cases in which third parties claim infringement of their patents, including certain cases where infringement claims have been made against its customers in connection with products the applicable Alcatel-Lucent entity has
provided to them, or challenging the validity of certain patents. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Microsoft
 </FONT></I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Lucent, Microsoft and Dell have been involved in a number of patent lawsuits in various
jurisdictions. In the summer of 2003, certain Dell and Microsoft lawsuits in San Diego, California, were consolidated in federal court in the Southern District of California. The court scheduled a number of trials for groups of the Lucent patents,
including two trials held in 2008. In one of these trials, on April&nbsp;4, 2008, a jury awarded Alcatel-Lucent approximately US$&nbsp;357&nbsp;million in damages for Microsoft&#146;s infringement of the &#147;Day&#148; patent, which relates to a
computerized form entry system. On June&nbsp;19, 2008, the Court entered </FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>86</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report 2010 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
judgment on the verdict and also awarded prejudgment interest exceeding US$&nbsp;140&nbsp;million. The total amount awarded Alcatel-Lucent relating to the Day patent exceeded
US$&nbsp;497&nbsp;million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On December&nbsp;15, 2008, Microsoft and Alcatel-Lucent executed a settlement and license
agreement whereby the parties agreed to settle the majority of their outstanding litigations, with the exception of Microsoft&#146;s appeal of the Day patent verdict to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. This settlement included
dismissing all pending patent claims in which Alcatel-Lucent is a defendant and provided Alcatel-Lucent with licenses to all Microsoft patents-in-suit in these cases. Also, on May&nbsp;13, 2009, Alcatel-Lucent and Dell agreed to a settlement and
dismissal of the appeal issues relating to Dell from the April&nbsp;2008 trial. </FONT></P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On September&nbsp;11, 2009, the
Federal Circuit issued its opinion affirming that the Day patent is both a valid patent and infringed by Microsoft in Microsoft Outlook, Microsoft Money, and Windows Mobile products. However, the Federal Circuit vacated the jury&#146;s damages award
and ordered a new trial in the District Court in San Diego to re-calculate the amount of damages owed to Alcatel-Lucent for Microsoft&#146;s infringement. On November&nbsp;23, 2009, the Federal Circuit denied Microsoft&#146;s <I>en banc</I> petition
for a rehearing on the validity of the Day patent. </FONT></P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">On February&nbsp;22, 2010, Microsoft filed a Petition for a
Writ of Certiorari in the United States Supreme Court asking the Supreme Court to
</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
review the Federal Circuit&#146;s September&nbsp;11, 2009 decision to affirm the District Court&#146;s finding that Microsoft&#146;s Outlook, Money and Windows Mobile products infringed the Day
patent owned by Alcatel-Lucent USA Inc. On April&nbsp;23, 2010, Alcatel-Lucent USA Inc. filed its Brief in Opposition and the Supreme Court denied Microsoft&#146;s Petition on May&nbsp;24, 2010. A trial is scheduled for December&nbsp;3, 2010 in US
District Court in San Diego to determine the amount of compensation owed to Alcatel-Lucent USA Inc. by Microsoft for its infringement of the Day patent. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">In a parallel proceeding, the United States Patent and Trademark Office issued a Reexamination Certificate on March&nbsp;2, 2010
confirming the validity of the Day patent in response to a reexamination request filed by Dell in May of 2007. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="3" COLOR="#333333">g/ Effect
of the various proceedings </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">Governmental investigations and legal proceedings are subject to uncertainties
and the outcomes thereof are difficult to predict. Consequently, Alcatel-Lucent is unable to estimate the ultimate aggregate amount of monetary liability or financial impact with respect to these matters. Because of the uncertainties of government
investigations and legal proceedings, one or more of these matters could ultimately result in material monetary payments by Alcatel-Lucent beyond those to be made by reason of the various settlement agreements described in this Note&nbsp;23.
</FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#333333"></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5"><B><I><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#333333">N<SMALL>OTE
</SMALL> 24. E<SMALL>VENTS</SMALL> <SMALL>AFTER</SMALL> <SMALL>THE</SMALL> <SMALL>STATEMENT</SMALL> <SMALL>OF</SMALL> <SMALL>FINANCIAL</SMALL> <SMALL>POSITION</SMALL> <SMALL>DATE</SMALL> </FONT></I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:left; margin-right:1%; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:19px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">There were no events that should be disclosed or adjusted that occurred between
June&nbsp;30, 2010, date of the statement of financial position, and
</FONT></P></DIV><DIV STYLE="position:relative;float:right; width:48%;padding-right:9px;padding-bottom:8px;overflow:hidden">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2" COLOR="#333333">
July&nbsp;29, 2010, the date when the Board of Directors authorized the condensed consolidated financial statements for issue.
</FONT></P></DIV><br clear="All">
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Alcatel-Lucent First Half Report
2010&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="5" COLOR="#5f46a9"><B>87</B></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> </FONT></P>
